case_name: Durgah Committee, Ajmer v. State of Rajasthan & Municipal Committee, Ajmer

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 162 of 1959 was filed by special leave in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 162 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 13, 1959, of the Ra

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court delivered judgment and order dated January 13, 1959 in D. B. Criminal Revision No. 47 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 13, 1959, of the Rajasthan High Court in D. B. Criminal Revision No. 47 of 1957.

facts.text: Judgment of the Supreme Court was delivered on April 24, 1961 by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: C. P. Lal, for the appellant. Mukat Behari Lal Bhargava and Naunit Lal, for respondent No.2. 1961. April 24. The Judgment of the Court was deliv

facts.text: Municipal Committee, Ajmer (respondent 2) issued a notice to the appellant, Durgah Committee, Ajmer, on June 13, 1950 under s. 153 of the Ajmer-Merwara Municipalities Regulation, 1925 for repairs to Jhalra Wall in dilapidated condition.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-On June 13,1950, the Municipal Committee, Ajmer, respondent 2, issued a numberice against the appellant, the Durgah Committee, Ajmer, under s. 153 of the Ajmer- Merwara Municipalities Regulation, 1925  VI of 1925   hereafter called the Regulation  calling upon it to carry out certain repairs in the Jhalra Wall which was in a dilapidated companydition.

facts.text: Appellant did not comply with the requisition notice issued under s.153.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant did number companyply with the said requisition and so respondent 2 served another numberice on the appellant under s. 220 of the Regulation inti-

facts.text: Respondent 2 served another notice on appellant under s.220 on July 3, 1950, intimating repairs would be carried out at respondent 2's expense recoverable from appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant did number companyply with the said requisition and so respondent 2 served another numberice on the appellant under s. 220 of the Regulation inti- mating to it that the required repairs would be carried out at the expense of respondent 2 and that the companyt incurred by it would be recovered from the appellant. This numberice was served on July 3, 1950.

facts.text: Appellant took no steps to make the repairs after s.220 notice.

anchor.surface_text: Even so the appellant took numbersteps to make the repairs and so respondent 2 proceeded to get the repair work done at its expense which amounted to Rs. 17,414.

facts.text: Respondent 2 carried out the repair work at its expense amounting to Rs. 17,414.

anchor.surface_text: Even so the appellant took numbersteps to make the repairs and so respondent 2 proceeded to get the repair work done at its expense which amounted to Rs. 17,414. Under s. 222 4  of the Regulation this sum became recoverable from the appellant as a tax.

facts.text: Notice of demand for Rs.17,414 was issued to appellant on April 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 222 4  of the Regulation this sum became recoverable from the appellant as a tax. A numberice of demand in that behalf was issued on the appellant on April 1, 1952, and in pursuance of the said numberice respondent 2 applied to the Additional Tehsildar and Magistrate II Class, Ajmer, for the recovery of the said amount under s. 234 of the Regulation.

facts.text: Respondent 2 applied to Additional Tehsildar and Magistrate II Class, Ajmer for recovery under s.234.

anchor.surface_text: A numberice of demand in that behalf was issued on the appellant on April 1, 1952, and in pursuance of the said numberice respondent 2 applied to the Additional Tehsildar and Magistrate II Class, Ajmer, for the recovery of the said amount under s. 234 of the Regulation. In the proceedings before the learned Magistrate the appellant raised certain pleas.

facts.text: Appellant raised certain pleas before the Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: In the proceedings before the learned Magistrate the appellant raised certain pleas. These pleas were rejected and an order was passed calling upon the appellant to pay the dues in question by August 30, 1956.

facts.text: Magistrate rejected appellant's pleas and ordered payment of dues by August 30, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: These pleas were rejected and an order was passed calling upon the appellant to pay the dues in question by August 30, 1956. Against this order the appellant preferred a criminal revision application in the Court of the Sessions Judge, Ajmer.

facts.text: Appellant filed criminal revision to Sessions Judge, Ajmer against Magistrate's order.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order the appellant preferred a criminal revision application in the Court of the Sessions Judge, Ajmer. The learned Sessions Judge companysidered the companytentions raised by the appellant and held that the view taken by the Magistrate cannot be said to be incorrect and so there was numberground to interfere in revision.

facts.text: Sessions Judge, Ajmer dismissed the revision holding no ground to interfere.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge companysidered the companytentions raised by the appellant and held that the view taken by the Magistrate cannot be said to be incorrect and so there was numberground to interfere in revision. Feeling aggrieved by the dismissal of its revision application the appellant moved the High Court of Judicature for Rajasthan in its revisional jurisdiction.

facts.text: Appellant filed criminal revision in Rajasthan High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Feeling aggrieved by the dismissal of its revision application the appellant moved the High Court of Judicature for Rajasthan in its revisional jurisdiction. Before the High Court, on behalf of respondent 1, the State of Rajasthan, as well as respondent 2, a preliminary objection was raised that the criminal revision application filed by the appellant was incompetent since the Magistrate who entertained respondent 2s application made under s. 234 ,as number an inferior criminal companyrt under s. 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

facts.text: Respondents raised preliminary objection in High Court that revision incompetent as Magistrate not inferior criminal court u/s 439 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: Before the High Court, on behalf of respondent 1, the State of Rajasthan, as well as respondent 2, a preliminary objection was raised that the criminal revision application filed by the appellant was incompetent since the Magistrate who entertained respondent 2s application made under s. 234 ,as number an inferior criminal companyrt under s. 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. This preliminary objection was upheld by the High Court and the criminal revision application dismissed on that ground.

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court upheld preliminary objection and dismissed revision.

anchor.surface_text: This preliminary objection was upheld by the High Court and the criminal revision application dismissed on that ground. It is against this order that the appellant has companye to this Court by special leave and the short question which the appeal raises for our decision is whether the Magistrate who entertained the application made before him by respondent 2 under s. 234 was an inferior criminal companyrt under s. 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

facts.text: No rules framed under the Regulation prescribing form for demand notice under s.222(1).

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chatterjee also attempted to argue that the proceedings under s. 234 taken against the appellant by respondent 2 were incompetent because a demand, has number been made by respondent 2 on the appellant in the manner prescribed by rule as required by s. 234. It does appear that rules have number been framed under the Regulation and so numberform has been prescribed for making a demand under s. 222 1 .

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Magistrate entertaining s.234 application is not inferior criminal court u/s439 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: He cannot therefore be regarded as an inferior criminal companyrt. That is the view taken by the High Court and we see numberreason to differ from it.

facts.text: Appellant argued proceedings under s.234 incompetent due to no demand in prescribed manner.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chatterjee also attempted to argue that the proceedings under s. 234 taken against the appellant by respondent 2 were incompetent because a demand, has number been made by respondent 2 on the appellant in the manner prescribed by rule as required by s. 234.

facts.text: Supreme Court rejected appellant's argument on incompetence of s.234 proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, the companytention that the application made under s. 234 was incompetent must be rejected.

It is against this order that the appellant has come to this Court by special leave and the short question which the appeal raises for our decision is whether the Magistrate who entertained the application made before him by respondent 2 under s. 234 was an inferior criminal court under s. 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

concepts.interpretation: Magistrate entertaining application under s.234 of the Regulation is not an inferior criminal court under s.439 CrPC as he acts as persona designata.

anchor.surface_text: Section 93 provides for appeals against taxation. Section 93(1) lays down, inter alia, that an appeal against the assessment or levy of any tax under this Regulation shall lie to the Deputy Commissioner or to such officer as may be empowered by the State Government in this behalf.

concepts.interpretation: Appeal lies against levy of tax, including deemed tax under s.222(4).

concepts.interpretation: Stays enforcement pending appeal against s.222 order.

anchor.surface_text: In Re Dinbai Jijibhai Khambatta the Bombay High Court held that the order made by a Magistrate under s. 161(2) of the Bombay District Municipalities Act, 1901 can be revised by the High Court under s. 435 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 162 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 13, 1959, of the Rajasthan High Court in D. B. Criminal Revision No. 47 of 1957.

Before the High Court, on behalf of respondent 1, the State of Rajasthan, as well as respondent 2, a preliminary objection was raised that the criminal revision application filed by the appellant was incompetent since the Magistrate who entertained respondent 2's application made under s. 234, was not an inferior criminal court under s. 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

precedents.citation: Crown through Municipal Committee, Ajmer v. Amba Lal 1

anchor.surface_text: Crown through Municipal Committee, Ajmer v. Amba Lal 1 , the Judicial Commissioner Mr. Norman held that a Magistrate entertaining an application under s. 234 of the Regulation is an inferior criminal companyrt.

precedents.case_name: Crown through Municipal Committee, Ajmer v. Amba Lal
precedents.cited_proposition: a Magistrate entertaining an application under s. 234 of the Regulation is an inferior criminal court

anchor.surface_text: Re Dinbai Jijibhai Khambatta 2  the Bombay High Court held that the order made, by a Magistrate under s. 161 2  of the Bombay District Municipalities Act, 1901  Bombay III of 1901  can be revised by the High Court under s. 435 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

precedents.cited_proposition: the order made by a Magistrate under s. 161 2  of the Bombay District Municipalities Act, 1901 can be revised by the High Court under s. 435 of the Code of Criminal Procedure

precedents.citation: V. B. DMonte v. Bandra Borough Municipality 1

anchor.surface_text: V. B. DMonte v. Bandra Borough Municipality 1  a Full Bench of the Bombay High Court, while dealing with a corresponding provision of the Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act XVIII of 1925, namely, s. 110, has held that in exercising its revisional jurisdiction under s. 110 the High Court is exercising a special jurisdiction conferred upon it by the said section and not the jurisdiction conferred under s. 435 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

precedents.case_name: V. B. DMonte v. Bandra Borough Municipality
precedents.cited_proposition: in exercising its revisional jurisdiction under s. 110 the High Court is exercising a special jurisdiction conferred upon it by the said section and not the jurisdiction conferred under s. 435 of the Code of Criminal Procedure
precedents.cited_holding: the matter coming before the High Court in such revision is of civil nature and so the revisional application would lie to the High Court on its civil side and not on its criminal side

anchor.surface_text: Emperor v. Devappa Ramappa  1  which took a contrary view was not followed.
Re Dalsukhram Hurgovandas  2  the Bombay High Court had occasion to consider the nature of the proceedings contemplated by s. 86 of the Bombay District Municipal Act III of 1901.

precedents.cited_proposition: in hearing the said appeals the Magistrate is merely an appellate authority having jurisdiction to deal with questions of civil liability. He is therefore not an inferior criminal court and as such his orders are not subject to the revisional jurisdiction of the High Court under s. 435 of the Code of Criminal Procedure

anchor.surface_text: Municipal Committee, Lashkar v. Shahabuddin  3 . Under the said section an application can be made by the Municipality for recovering the cost of the work from the person in default.

precedents.cited_proposition: the order passed in the said proceedings cannot be revised by the High Court under s. 435 because the order is an administrative order and that there was no doubt that the Magistrate was not an inferior criminal court

precedents.citation: Mithan Musammat v. The Municipal Board of Agra Anr., 4

anchor.surface_text: Mithan Musammat v. The Municipal Board of Agra Anr.,  4  the Allahabad High Court has held that a Magistrate passing an order under s. 247 1  of the United Provinces Municipalities Act, 1926 does not do so as an inferior criminal court within the meaning of s. 435 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

precedents.case_name: Mithan Musammat v. The Municipal Board of Agra Anr.
precedents.cited_proposition: a Magistrate passing an order under s. 247 1  of the United Provinces Municipalities Act, 1926 does not do so as an inferior criminal court within the meaning of s. 435 of the Code of Criminal Procedure

anchor.surface_text: Madho Ram v. Rex  1 . We have referred to these decisions only to illustrate that in dealing with similar provisions under the municipal law different High Courts seem to have taken the view that Magistrates entertaining recovery proceedings under the appropriate statutory provisions are not inferior criminal courts under the Code of Criminal Procedure.

precedents.cited_proposition: a Magistrate passing an order under relevant section does not do so as an inferior criminal court within the meaning of s. 435 of the Code of Criminal Procedure
